game.title: The Monty Hall Problem

about.title: About Monty Hall
about.text: In the Monty Hall problem you are a contestant at a game show. You will be offered the choice between opening three different doors. Behind one of them is the prize, a sports car, but behind the other two there are goats. At first, you select a door that you wish to open, however, then the host opens a different door than what you chose and reveals a goat behind it. You are then asked, "Would you like to switch to the other door?". The choice you then make, is the prize that you win.

game.start: Click on the door you think has the prize!
game.switch: Do you want to switch? Select your final door.

statistics.title: Test the Probability

about.title: About the Probability
about.text: For most people I have talked to, the intuitive assumption is that the choice between keeping or changing your door is insignificant. That it is either way a 50% chance of winning. I was suprised when I learnt that this is not the case. It is a 1/3 chance that the initial selection is correct and a 2/3 likelihood of the price being behind one of the other doors. When a goat is shown behind one of these doors, this 2/3 likelihood is transfered to the remaining closed door, while the initial selected door still only has a 1/3 chance of being right. To sum it up, switching gives you a 2/3 chance of success, while staying only gives you a 1/3 chance of success.
